title: China Eximbank provides RMB 500 million government concessional loan for Simon Bolivar Highway Extension Project
description: On February 2, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Ecuador signed a RMB 500 million ($77,380,000) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2013) 13 TOTAL NO. (458) No. 1420203052013110101] for the Simon Bolivar Highway Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 5 year grace period, a maturity of 20 years, a 0.75% commitment fee, and a 1% management fee.  The borrower was expected to used the proceeds of the loan to finance a $78,998,000 commercial contract [REI-EPMMOP-PSB-001-2012] between Empresa Pública Metropolitana de Movilidad y Obras Públicas (EPMMOP) — a state-owned mobility and public works company in Ecuador — and Sinohydro Corporation Limited, which was signed on November 9, 2012.   The loan’s (principal) outstanding amount was $56,633,099.07 as of December 31, 2021 and $46,341,422.03 as of November 30, 2022.  The purpose of this 12 km Simon Bolivar Highway Project was to connect the capital city of Quito with the newly-opened Mariscal Sucre International Airport.   Sinohydro Corporation Limited was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by EPMMOP, which is a state-owned mobility and public works company in Ecuador. Project implementation commenced on May 6, 2013. The highway was opened to traffic on June 15, 2018. The originally expected project commencement and completion dates were December 24, 2013 and April 24, 2016, respectively.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Prolongation of the Simon Bolivar Avenue Project. The Chinese project title is 厄瓜多尔西蒙玻利瓦尔大道延长线项目. 2. The China Eximbank loan contract can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20488191-ecu_2013_442_1_of_2. 3. The commercial contract between EPMMOP and Sinohydro Corporation Limited can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/jv4hp8e7s80il7x/2.%20CONTRATO%20PRINCIPAL.pdfdl=0.4. The Ecuadorian Ministry of Finance loan identification number is 23170000.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 500 million government concessional loan for Simon Bolivar Highway Extension Project

# Description
On February 2, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Ecuador signed a RMB 500 million ($77,380,000) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2013) 13 TOTAL NO. (458) No. 1420203052013110101] for the Simon Bolivar Highway Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 5 year grace period, a maturity of 20 years, a 0.75% commitment fee, and a 1% management fee.  The borrower was expected to used the proceeds of the loan to finance a $78,998,000 commercial contract [REI-EPMMOP-PSB-001-2012] between Empresa Pública Metropolitana de Movilidad y Obras Públicas (EPMMOP) — a state-owned mobility and public works company in Ecuador — and Sinohydro Corporation Limited, which was signed on November 9, 2012.   The loan’s (principal) outstanding amount was $56,633,099.07 as of December 31, 2021 and $46,341,422.03 as of November 30, 2022.  The purpose of this 12 km Simon Bolivar Highway Project was to connect the capital city of Quito with the newly-opened Mariscal Sucre International Airport.   Sinohydro Corporation Limited was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by EPMMOP, which is a state-owned mobility and public works company in Ecuador. Project implementation commenced on May 6, 2013. The highway was opened to traffic on June 15, 2018. The originally expected project commencement and completion dates were December 24, 2013 and April 24, 2016, respectively.
justification: Highway construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 12 km highway connecting Quito to Mariscal Sucre International Airport, transportation infrastructure focus

title: China Eximbank provides $312.4 million buyer's credit loan for 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#93434 and #96295)
description: On April 10, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Ecuador signed a $312,480,966.99 buyer's credit loan (BCL) agreement (Contract No. 1410302052013210568) for the 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The BCL carried the following borrowing terms: an annual interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 4.2% margin, a grace period of 4 years, and a maturity of 15 years. It is backed by a credit insurance policy from Sinosure.   As of December 2018, the loan had achieved an 31.9% disbursement rate ($99,967,764.14 out of $312,480,967). The borrower made principal repayments worth $15,624,048.35 on September 21, 2018, $15,624,048.35 on March 21, 2019, $15,624,048.35 on September 21, 2019, $15,624,048.35 on March 21, 2020, and $19,229,597.97 on March 21, 2022. It did not make any principal repayments on the originally scheduled repayment dates of September 21, 2020, March 21, 2021, September 21, 2021, and September 21, 2022. The loan’s (principal) amount outstanding was $298,856,918.64 September 21, 2018, $281,232,870.29 as of March 21, 2019, $265,608,821.94 as of September 21, 2019, $249,984,773.59 as of March 21, 2020, $249,984,773.59 as of September 21, 2020, $249,984,773.59 as of March 21, 2021, $249,984,773.59 as of September 21, 2021, $249,984,773.59 as of December 31, 2021, $230,755,175.62 as of March 21, 2022, $230,755,175.62 as of September 21, 2022, and $230,755,175.62 as of November 30, 2022.  The purpose of the project was to construct the 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant in the southwest province of Azuay and the cantons of El Oro, Pucará, Zaruma and Pasaje. Upon completion, the power plant was expected to have a maximum annual power generation capacity of 1.291 billion kWh and reduce carbon emissions by 690,000 tons each year. Minas San Francisco is made up of a 54-m-high rolled concrete gravity-type dam that generates a regulation and control reservoir, an intake work located on the right bank of the Jubones River that connects with a 13.9 km driving tunnel. The pressure pipe is developed in two sections that comprise a total drop of 474 meter. The underground powerhouse houses three Pelton-type turbines of 90 MW each.  Harbin Electric International Company Limited was the general contractor responsible for implementation. Its work was overseen by Corporación Eléctrica del Ecuador (CELEC) and Ministerio de Electricidad y Energía Renovable (MEER). Construction began in March 2012. The excavation of a diversion tunnel was completed in August 2013. The diversion of the Jubones River took place in February 2014. Then, in January 2015, the excavation of the entrance window to the head tunnel was complete. The completion of the powerhouse excavation took place in October 2015. Then, in December 2016, the construction and assembly of the transmission line was completed. The power plant’s three generator rotors were lowered into place between January 2017 and May 2017. The filling of the reservoir occurred in December 2017. Then, in May 2018, the first rotation of the first turbine-generator took place. As of August 2018, the project had achieved a 99.7% completion rate. All three power generation units were connected to the grid on October 24, 2018. The first power generation unit was officially inaugurated on January 15, 2019. The project’s official handover ceremony took place on April 9, 2021.   To date, the power plant has reportedly generated over 140 million kWh power, created more than 2,000 jobs, and delivered electricity on a daily basis to nearly 1.2 million people and 2,000 manufacturing companies. However, the project suffered multiple setbacks due to administrative and technical discrepancies with contractors and inspectors, as well as the COVID-19 pandemic. The China Eximbank loan (BCL) that supported this project also underperformed. It was rescheduled twice — once in September 2020 (as captured via Project ID#93434) and again in September 2022 (as captured via Project ID#96295).
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 厄瓜多尔米纳斯圣弗朗西斯科水电站项目. The Spanish project title is La Central Hidroeléctrica Minas San Francisco de 270 MW. 2. The all-in interest was estimated by adding 4.2% to the average 6 month Libor rate in April 2013 (0.154%). 3. The Ministry of Finance SAP code for this project is 202021003.4. The September 2022 loan rescheduling agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/7y7w2q91up5ukcn/13%20September%202022%20Amendment%20Agreement%20related%20to%20BCL%20for%20Minas%20San%20Francisco%20Project.pdf?dl=0. The revised loan amortization table (repayment schedule) can be accessed on pg. 6.5.   The Ecuadorian Ministry of Finance loan identification number is 23171000
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $312.4 million buyer's credit loan for 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#93434 and #96295)

# Description
On April 10, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Ecuador signed a $312,480,966.99 buyer's credit loan (BCL) agreement (Contract No. 1410302052013210568) for the 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The BCL carried the following borrowing terms: an annual interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 4.2% margin, a grace period of 4 years, and a maturity of 15 years. It is backed by a credit insurance policy from Sinosure.   As of December 2018, the loan had achieved an 31.9% disbursement rate ($99,967,764.14 out of $312,480,967). The borrower made principal repayments worth $15,624,048.35 on September 21, 2018, $15,624,048.35 on March 21, 2019, $15,624,048.35 on September 21, 2019, $15,624,048.35 on March 21, 2020, and $19,229,597.97 on March 21, 2022. It did not make any principal repayments on the originally scheduled repayment dates of September 21, 2020, March 21, 2021, September 21, 2021, and September 21, 2022. The loan’s (principal) amount outstanding was $298,856,918.64 September 21, 2018, $281,232,870.29 as of March 21, 2019, $265,608,821.94 as of September 21, 2019, $249,984,773.59 as of March 21, 2020, $249,984,773.59 as of September 21, 2020, $249,984,773.59 as of March 21, 2021, $249,984,773.59 as of September 21, 2021, $249,984,773.59 as of December 31, 2021, $230,755,175.62 as of March 21, 2022, $230,755,175.62 as of September 21, 2022, and $230,755,175.62 as of November 30, 2022.  The purpose of the project was to construct the 275MW Minas-San Francisco Hydroelectric Power Plant in the southwest province of Azuay and the cantons of El Oro, Pucará, Zaruma and Pasaje. Upon completion, the power plant was expected to have a maximum annual power generation capacity of 1.291 billion kWh and reduce carbon emissions by 690,000 tons each year. Minas San Francisco is made up of a 54-m-high rolled concrete gravity-type dam that generates a regulation and control reservoir, an intake work located on the right bank of the Jubones River that connects with a 13.9 km driving tunnel. The pressure pipe is developed in two sections that comprise a total drop of 474 meter. The underground powerhouse houses three Pelton-type turbines of 90 MW each.  Harbin Electric International Company Limited was the general contractor responsible for implementation. Its work was overseen by Corporación Eléctrica del Ecuador (CELEC) and Ministerio de Electricidad y Energía Renovable (MEER). Construction began in March 2012. The excavation of a diversion tunnel was completed in August 2013. The diversion of the Jubones River took place in February 2014. Then, in January 2015, the excavation of the entrance window to the head tunnel was complete. The completion of the powerhouse excavation took place in October 2015. Then, in December 2016, the construction and assembly of the transmission line was completed. The power plant’s three generator rotors were lowered into place between January 2017 and May 2017. The filling of the reservoir occurred in December 2017. Then, in May 2018, the first rotation of the first turbine-generator took place. As of August 2018, the project had achieved a 99.7% completion rate. All three power generation units were connected to the grid on October 24, 2018. The first power generation unit was officially inaugurated on January 15, 2019. The project’s official handover ceremony took place on April 9, 2021.   To date, the power plant has reportedly generated over 140 million kWh power, created more than 2,000 jobs, and delivered electricity on a daily basis to nearly 1.2 million people and 2,000 manufacturing companies. However, the project suffered multiple setbacks due to administrative and technical discrepancies with contractors and inspectors, as well as the COVID-19 pandemic. The China Eximbank loan (BCL) that supported this project also underperformed. It was rescheduled twice — once in September 2020 (as captured via Project ID#93434) and again in September 2022 (as captured via Project ID#96295).
justification: Primary purpose is hydroelectric power generation with clear renewable energy focus and significant carbon reduction potential
evidence: 275MW hydroelectric power plant, expected annual power generation of 1.291 billion kWh, carbon emissions reduction of 690,000 tons annually

title: Bank of China and Deutsche Bank (China) provide $298.9 million syndicated loan for the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project
description: On July 24, 2013, the Republic of Ecuador signed a $298,880,591.93 syndicated loan agreement [identification number: 0033039-0000070 BJ: 1749986.10] with Bank of China Limited and Deutsche Bank (China) Co., Ltd. for the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project. This oil-backed loan carried the following borrowing terms: a variable interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 3.50% margin, a 3% default (penalty) interest rate, a 4 year grace period, a 14 year year maturity, a 0.75% commitment fee, and a 1% management fee. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance two commercial contracts (no. 2012-061 and 2012-062) worth $351,624,225.80 between China International Water & Electric Corporation and Secretaria Nacional del Agua (Senagua), which were signed on August 8, 2012 and August 9, 2012.   The loan’s (principal) outstanding amount was $179,328,355.13 as of December 31, 2021 and $149,440,295.93 as of November 30, 2022.   The purpose of the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project was to set fluvial defenses along the Cañar river, and thereby protect some 37,000 hectares and 176 km along the river and its effluents, as well as Patul, Piedras, Norcay rivers and the Trobador streams. With a total of 10 gates, the project sought to regulate up to 1,500 m3/s of water coming from the overflows of the river, to a 23 km long bypass which will have a deposit in La Lagartera lakes, which was designed to store 14 million cubic meters of water for irrigation.   The project was carried out by China International Water & Electric Corporation (CWE). It was originally scheduled for completion in August 2015. However, the $393.8 million contract with CWE did not become effective until 2015.  Construction began on April 21, 2015. Project activities included the construction of a diversion dam; the construction of a 23 km long canal; the construction of 2 bridges; and the rehabilitation of 4 bridges. The project fed river water to eight giant Chinese turbines designed to produce enough electricity to power more than a third of Ecuador. The project was completed and handed over to the authorities on January 12, 2016.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is ‘厄瓜多尔可尼尔防洪工程项目是公司在厄’ or '可尼尔防洪项目' . The Spanish project title is Construcción del Sistema de Control de Inundaciones Naranjal and Construcción del Sistema de Control de Inundaciones Cañar. 2. AidData has estimated the all-in interest rate (3.909%) by adding 3.5% to average 6-month LIBOR in July 2013 (0.409%).3. The Ecuadorian Ministry of Finance loan identification number is 28082000.4. The loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20488202-ecu_2013_446
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Bank of China and Deutsche Bank (China) provide $298.9 million syndicated loan for the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project

# Description
On July 24, 2013, the Republic of Ecuador signed a $298,880,591.93 syndicated loan agreement [identification number: 0033039-0000070 BJ: 1749986.10] with Bank of China Limited and Deutsche Bank (China) Co., Ltd. for the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project. This oil-backed loan carried the following borrowing terms: a variable interest rate of 6 month LIBOR plus a 3.50% margin, a 3% default (penalty) interest rate, a 4 year grace period, a 14 year year maturity, a 0.75% commitment fee, and a 1% management fee. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance two commercial contracts (no. 2012-061 and 2012-062) worth $351,624,225.80 between China International Water & Electric Corporation and Secretaria Nacional del Agua (Senagua), which were signed on August 8, 2012 and August 9, 2012.   The loan’s (principal) outstanding amount was $179,328,355.13 as of December 31, 2021 and $149,440,295.93 as of November 30, 2022.   The purpose of the Cañar and Naranjal Flood Control Project was to set fluvial defenses along the Cañar river, and thereby protect some 37,000 hectares and 176 km along the river and its effluents, as well as Patul, Piedras, Norcay rivers and the Trobador streams. With a total of 10 gates, the project sought to regulate up to 1,500 m3/s of water coming from the overflows of the river, to a 23 km long bypass which will have a deposit in La Lagartera lakes, which was designed to store 14 million cubic meters of water for irrigation.   The project was carried out by China International Water & Electric Corporation (CWE). It was originally scheduled for completion in August 2015. However, the $393.8 million contract with CWE did not become effective until 2015.  Construction began on April 21, 2015. Project activities included the construction of a diversion dam; the construction of a 23 km long canal; the construction of 2 bridges; and the rehabilitation of 4 bridges. The project fed river water to eight giant Chinese turbines designed to produce enough electricity to power more than a third of Ecuador. The project was completed and handed over to the authorities on January 12, 2016.
justification: Primary purpose is flood control and irrigation infrastructure, with no direct energy transition impact
evidence: Flood control project with irrigation components, construction of diversion dam and canal, rehabilitation of bridges

title: Chinese Embassy donates computers to public schools for incorporation of ICT in education
description: In 2013, the Chinese Embassy provided $4,000,000 worth of computers to public schools for a project to incorporate ICT (Information and Communications Technology) into education. The executing agency is the Ecuador Ministry of Education (Ministerio de Educacion; MINEDU).
staff_comments: Unable to find additional sources confirming project. May be related to, or a duplicate of, project ID#59176.

title: Chinese Embassy funds development seminars and workshops
description: From 2013 to 2014, the Chinese Embassy provided $1,540,000 to fund seminars and workshops on development in several areas. The executing agency was the Ecuador Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture, and Fisheries (Ministerio de Agricultura, Ganaderia, Acuacultura, y Pesca; MAGAP).
staff_comments: The year is unclear, the map source lists the project under 2013 and 2014. The Ministerio de Agricultura y Ganaderia source has articles on multiple development seminars from those years, however there is no information on their funding.

title: MOFCOM provides grant for Solar Street Light Project
description: According to Shenzhen Spike Optoelectronics Technology Co., Ltd (SPARK), in February 2013, the Foreign Aid Department of China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Bureau of Renewable Energy within the Egyptian Ministry of Electricity and Energy initiated a Solar Street Light Project. With funding from MOFCOM, a contractor named SPARKOE installed 315 sets of 60W solar street lamps. The street lamps measure 8 meters in height and are spaced 30 meters apart. The project was completed in July 2013.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Egypt Split Type Solar Street Light Aid Project. The Chinese project title is 埃及-分体式太阳能路灯援外项目. It is unclear whether this project took place at or near the Kuraymat Solar Power Station. This issue merits further investigation.

With funding from MOFCOM, a contractor named SPARKOE installed 315 sets of 60W solar street lamps. The street lamps measure 8 meters in height and are spaced 30 meters apart. evidence: Installation of 315 sets of 60W solar street lamps, funded by MOFCOM for renewable energy purposes

title: China Eximbank provides $203.15 million buyer’s credit loan for Bata University Campus Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#484)
description: In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility agreement for various infrastructure projects (captured in Project ID#484). All subsidiary loans approved under this facility agreement carry the following terms: a 5.5% interest rate, 5 year maturity, and 2 year grace period. Then, in 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Bata University Campus Construction Project. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to finance a $239 million (or 120 billion CFA) commercial contract with China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC), which was signed on June 4, 2013. The estimated face value of loan is $203.15 million (since other subsidiary buyer’s credit loans that were approved through the $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility were use to finance 85% of commercial contract costs).   This project involves the construction of the Bata campus of the Universidad Nacional de Guinea Ecuatorial (UNGE). The campus was designed to can accommodate 4000 students and 400 faculty. Construction began on or around June 4, 2014. As of July 2018, construction was still ongoing. By 2019, the project had only achieved a 30% completion rate.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 和巴塔大学 or 巴塔大学项目. The Spanish project title is El Proyecto de Campus Universitario de Bata. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported Bata University Campus Construction Project is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020. Nor is it included it in the China’s Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University's Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:

# Description
In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility agreement for various infrastructure projects (captured in Project ID#484). All subsidiary loans approved under this facility agreement carry the following terms: a 5.5% interest rate, 5 year maturity, and 2 year grace period. Then, in 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Bata University Campus Construction Project. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to finance a $239 million (or 120 billion CFA) commercial contract with China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC), which was signed on June 4, 2013. The estimated face value of loan is $203.15 million (since other subsidiary buyer’s credit loans that were approved through the $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility were use to finance 85% of commercial contract costs).   This project involves the construction of the Bata campus of the Universidad Nacional de Guinea Ecuatorial (UNGE). The campus was designed to can accommodate 4000 students and 400 faculty. justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of university campus, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Dumasi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm Project
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government reportedly provided a grant to the Government of Equatorial Guinea for the Dumasi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm Project. The monetary value of this grant is unknown.  On October 20, 2015, Jiangxi Ganliang Industrial Ltd. completed the project. It was officially handed over to Equatorial Guinea’s Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of Equatorial Guinea on March 4, 2016.   Jiangxi Ganliang Industrial Ltd. selected agricultural experts to carry out crop diversification cultivation, improved seed breeding, production and processing demonstration, technology promotion and personnel training at the Dumasi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm in the town of Niefang. The farm covers an area of 52 hectares. The agricultural expert group launched a rice planting experiment in November 2017. Then, in May 2018, Dumasi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm grew a rice crop successfully for the first time in the history of the country. In order to promote the cultivation of rice within 10 acres of farmland, the Chinese agricultural expert group selected 4 high-yield  rice varieties suitable for local planting. It overcame various difficulties, including a low seedling survival rate, seedling transplanting problems, and fertilizer and water management challenges.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Dumassi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm Project. 2. The Chinese project title is 援赤几涅方示范农场项目. 3. The Spanish project title is La Granja Piloto y Experimental Agricola de Dumassi-Niefang or La Granja Piloto de Niefang or La Granja de Dumasi.
combined_text:

The farm covers an area of 52 hectares. The agricultural expert group launched a rice planting experiment in November 2017. Then, in May 2018, Dumasi-Niefang Agricultural Demonstration Farm grew a rice crop successfully for the first time in the history of the country. In order to promote the cultivation of rice within 10 acres of farmland, the Chinese agricultural expert group selected 4 high-yield  rice varieties suitable for local planting. justification: Agricultural development project focused on crop diversification and technology transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural demonstration farm, crop diversification, seed breeding, technology promotion, personnel training

title: CDB provides $185.7 million loan for Malabo University Campus Construction Project
description: On August 16, 2013, the Government of Equatorial Guinea and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) signed a $308.02 million (EUR 237.8 million) commercial contract for the Malabo University Campus Construction Project. China Development Bank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea subsequently singed an $185,703,156.66 loan agreement for the Malabo University Campus Construction Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance the commercial contract that was signed on August 16, 2013. According to Caja Autónoma de Amortización de la Deuda Pública within Equatorial Guinea’s Ministry of Finance and Budget, the CDB loan had not disbursed as of December 31, 2019. As such, no principal or interest repayments had been made as of December 31, 2019.   The purpose of the project is to construct a new campus for Malabo University in the city of Malabo. More specifically, the project involves the construction of educational buildings, administrative buildings, dormitories, and sports fields. CMEC is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced in 2013 and it was originally expected to require 30 months of implementation time. However, as of 2019, the project had only achieved a 60% completion rate. On September 22, 2019, CMEC Deputy Party Secretary and General Manager Han Xiaojun inspected the project site.
staff_comments: 1. The Spanish project title is Campus Universitário de Malabo or El Proyecto de Campus Universitario de Malabo. The Chinese project title is 赤道几内亚马拉博大学城项目 or 赤道幾內亞馬拉博大學城建設項目. 2. The CDB loan for the Malabo University Campus Construction Project is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020. Nor is it included it in the China’s Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University's Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 3. The face value of the loan is drawn from ‘Cuadro General de la deuda al 31/12/2019’ from the Caja Autónoma de Amortización de la Deuda Pública within Equatorial Guinea’s Ministry of Finance and Budget.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
CDB provides $185.7 million loan for Malabo University Campus Construction Project

# Description
On August 16, 2013, the Government of Equatorial Guinea and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) signed a $308.02 million (EUR 237.8 million) commercial contract for the Malabo University Campus Construction Project. China Development Bank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea subsequently singed an $185,703,156.66 loan agreement for the Malabo University Campus Construction Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance the commercial contract that was signed on August 16, 2013. According to Caja Autónoma de Amortización de la Deuda Pública within Equatorial Guinea’s Ministry of Finance and Budget, the CDB loan had not disbursed as of December 31, 2019. As such, no principal or interest repayments had been made as of December 31, 2019.   The purpose of the project is to construct a new campus for Malabo University in the city of Malabo. More specifically, the project involves the construction of educational buildings, administrative buildings, dormitories, and sports fields. CMEC is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project commenced in 2013 and it was originally expected to require 30 months of implementation time. However, as of 2019, the project had only achieved a 60% completion rate. On September 22, 2019, CMEC Deputy Party Secretary and General Manager Han Xiaojun inspected the project site.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of university campus including educational buildings, dormitories, and sports fields
